headline.main: 3 RUSSIANS RETURN AFTER RECORD 237 DAYS IN SPACE

results.snippet: Three Soviet astronauts who made history's longest space flight returned to the earth safely today and were pronounced well after almost eight months in weightless conditions, the official Soviet press agency Tass said.   The three, Leonid Kizim,...
results.lead_paragraph: Three Soviet astronauts who made history's longest space flight returned to the earth safely today and were pronounced well after almost eight months in weightless conditions, the official Soviet press agency Tass said. The three, Leonid Kizim, Vladimir Solovyov and Oleg Atkov, returned to the earth at 1:57 P.M., Moscow time, after spending 237 days in space, Tass said. The Soviet evening television news program showed their capsule wafting down under a red and white parachute, then a quick puff of fire and smoke as the craft's soft-landing engines fired.

headline.main: LARGEST CREW EVER SENT INTO SPACE BLENDS INTEREST IN FLIGHT AND SCIENCE

results.snippet: Kathryn D. Sullivan    Slated to spend three hours outside the spacecraft, she will be the first American woman to walk in space . . . says her interest in space grew out of her work in earth sciences . . . after graduating from the University of...
results.lead_paragraph: Kathryn D. Sullivan Slated to spend three hours outside the spacecraft, she will be the first American woman to walk in space . . . says her interest in space grew out of her work in earth sciences . . . after graduating from the University of California at Santa Cruz in 1973, she went on to earn a Ph.D. in geology from Dalhousie University in Canada . . . her dissertation concerned the structure of the continental shelf and deep sea floor off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland . . . participated in oceanographic expeditions of the U.S. Geological Survey and other institutions . . . joined NASA in 1978 as one of first six women to be astronaut candidates . . . at NASA her research has focused on remote sensing and planetary geology . . . a mountain climbing enthusiast, she has hiked in most major mountain ranges in North America and Europe . . . speaks five foreign languages . . . 31 years old and unmarried . . . went to high school in Woodland Hills, Calif., which she calls her home . . . her mother is deceased and her father, Donald P. Sullivan, formerly an aerospace design engineer with the Lockheed Corporation, lives in Cupertino, Calif. Marc Garneau As a child, never had a burning desire to be an astronaut but is now thrilled to be the first Canadian to venture into space . . . was selected as one of six Canadian astronauts last year after an intensive screening process . . . a 35-year-old commander in the Canadian Navy, will conduct 10 scientific experiments for his Government on the flight . . . the son of a career Army officer, was born in Quebec city, Quebec . . . received a degree in engineering physics from the Royal Military College of Kingston in 1970, and a Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the Imperial College of Science and Technology in London, England, in 1973 . . . points out that Canada was third nation to put its own satellite into orbit and that a Canadian concern built the shuttle's robot arm . . . says his countrymen are even prouder that a Canadian is finally going into space . . . married and the father of twins, has traveled extensively, including sailing the Atlantic twice in a 59-foot yawl . . . plays squash and tennis and likes to make wine.

results.snippet: A BIBLICAL injunction instructs farmers to leave a corner of the field for the poor to glean or pick. Since few Long Islanders have farms to leave ungleaned, a group from the Melville-Dix Hills area is doing what the members consider the next best...
results.lead_paragraph: A BIBLICAL injunction instructs farmers to leave a corner of the field for the poor to glean or pick. Since few Long Islanders have farms to leave ungleaned, a group from the Melville-Dix Hills area is doing what the members consider the next best thing: They are going out into the fields themselves to glean for the poor. Sponsored by the Social Action Committee of Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills, the group includes members of that congregation, of the Honor Society at Burr's Lane Junior High School, also in Dix Hills, and parishioners of King of Kings Lutheran Church in Melville. Several hundred people are expected to participate in today's gleaning project. They will wander into the fields, actually Meyer's Farm Stand, and, in the shadow of the Long Island Expressway, fill bushel baskets with string beans, tomatoes and green peppers hand-picked from the vines. The produce will then be donated to the Long Island Regional Food Bank for distribution to several day care facilities and centers for the elderly as well as emergency food pantries.

headline.main: 'REALLY GREAT,' SAYS THE FIRST WOMAN FROM U.S. TO TAKE A WALK IN SPACE

results.snippet: Dr. Kathryn D. Sullivan became the first American woman to walk in space today as she floated outside the shuttle Challenger and, with Lieut. Comdr. David C. Leestma, successfully tested a system for refueling satellites in space.     ''That is...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Kathryn D. Sullivan became the first American woman to walk in space today as she floated outside the shuttle Challenger and, with Lieut. Comdr. David C. Leestma, successfully tested a system for refueling satellites in space. ''That is really great,'' Dr. Sullivan said after she floated into the cargo bay of the shuttle with the earth circling about 140 miles below her. The two astronauts worked more than three hours, making a complex and not entirely risk-free job look easy. Hydrazine fuel can explode if it is overpressurized or heated, and escaping fumes can be toxic.

results.snippet: Although the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Challenger completed many tasks on their ambitious mission, their most visible success came at the end of the 13.5 million- mile journey: yesterday's precision landing in Florida, only three miles...

byline.original: By Richard Levine and Katherine Roberts

results.lead_paragraph: Although the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Challenger completed many tasks on their ambitious mission, their most visible success came at the end of the 13.5 million- mile journey: yesterday's precision landing in Florida, only three miles from the site of the shuttle's perfect lift-off eight days earlier. Landings in Florida - this was only the second in 13 flights - rather than in California eliminate the need to bring the shuttle back to Cape Canaveral and are seen as necessary to keep the shuttle on a once-a-month schedule.

headline.main: DAMAGE APPEARS NEGLIGIBLE IN FIRST INSPECTION OF SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Engineers began a detailed inspection of the space shuttle Challenger today to determine whether it had suffered much damage on its successful eight-day orbital trip.   The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said a preliminary look...
results.lead_paragraph: Engineers began a detailed inspection of the space shuttle Challenger today to determine whether it had suffered much damage on its successful eight-day orbital trip. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said a preliminary look following Saturday's perfect landing here showed that the shuttle had received some minor nicks on a few of its thermal tiles, which protect the craft from the heat of re-entering the earth's atmosphere. The space agency also said a strip of insulating tile was missing from the tail area. Engineers believe it was ripped away in the liftoff.

headline.main: MIDWEST REPUBLICANS GET HELP FROM GOOD REAGAN SHOWING

results.snippet: President Reagan's strong showing in the region where he grew up appears to be helping a number of Republicans seeking a wide variety of Federal and state political offices across the Middle West.    Political experts, backed by a range of...
results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan's strong showing in the region where he grew up appears to be helping a number of Republicans seeking a wide variety of Federal and state political offices across the Middle West. Political experts, backed by a range of published polls, indicate that Mr. Reagan holds a lead in almost every Middle Western state despite a chronic economic malaise that has struck both aging industries and beleaguered farms. According to one newspaper survey, Mr. Reagan even seems ahead of Walter F. Mondale in Mr. Mondale's home state, Minnesota. In what are regarded as the area's two closest races, those for Senate seats in Illinois and Iowa, the Republican incumbents, Senators Charles H. Percy and Roger W. Jepsen, have closely allied themselves with the Reagan Administration and appear to be counting on riding the President's coattails: He spent much of his early life in both states. Both races are considered crucial to Republican hopes of retaining control of the Senate, which now has 55 Republicans and 45 Democrats.

results.snippet: When Jack R. Lousma, Michigan's Republican nominee for the Senate, began campaigning against Senator Carl Levin, the Democratic incumbent, Republican strategists hoped he could capitalize on his career as an astronaut and on President Reagan's...
results.lead_paragraph: When Jack R. Lousma, Michigan's Republican nominee for the Senate, began campaigning against Senator Carl Levin, the Democratic incumbent, Republican strategists hoped he could capitalize on his career as an astronaut and on President Reagan's apparent popularity among union members. But less than a month before the election, Mr. Lousma's attacks on big government, high taxes and Mr. Levin's voting record do not appear to have caught on. Statewide polls indicate he is trailing Senator Levin, who in his six years in Washington has been a critic of the B-1 bomber, the MX missile system and high costs for spare parts of weapons. Last month, for example, in a poll by The Detroit News, Senator Levin was leading Mr. Lousma by 40 percentage points, 62 percent to 22 percent. In addition, 48 percent of those questioned said they did not know enough about the Republican candidate to make a decision.

headline.main: President of Air One Reports Accord on Sale

results.snippet: Air One Inc., a financially troubled commercial airline, may be on the brink of being bailed out.    In a terse announcement yesterday, Mark G. Morris, Air One's president, chief operating officer and founder, said the St. Louis-based airline had...
results.lead_paragraph: Air One Inc., a financially troubled commercial airline, may be on the brink of being bailed out. In a terse announcement yesterday, Mark G. Morris, Air One's president, chief operating officer and founder, said the St. Louis-based airline had entered into an agreement in principle to sell a controlling interest to the Southern Express Corporation, which is based in Austin, Tex. According to Air One, Southern Express would provide a ''multimillion-dollar'' investment as well as ''additional required capital'' to maintain the airline as a viable entity ''for the foreseeable future.''

results.snippet: ''INNOVATION,'' Channel 13's weekly science series, begins its third season at 8 tonight with ''The Extra-Terrestrial Scientists.'' Space is their laboratory, and in space they do interesting things. The half-hour program makes this comprehensible.
results.lead_paragraph: ''INNOVATION,'' Channel 13's weekly science series, begins its third season at 8 tonight with ''The Extra-Terrestrial Scientists.'' Space is their laboratory, and in space they do interesting things. The half-hour program makes this comprehensible.

results.snippet: The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. said today that they would begin admitting 5-year-old girls to a new category of Scout membership.    Until now, the youngest Girl Scouts have been Brownies, who can join at the age of 6. The new category will be the...
results.lead_paragraph: The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. said today that they would begin admitting 5-year-old girls to a new category of Scout membership. Until now, the youngest Girl Scouts have been Brownies, who can join at the age of 6. The new category will be the Daisy Girl Scouts, and it is the latest in a series of changes over the last 10 years that have added a contemporary flavor to the Girl Scouts' traditional values. The new troops will be set up as soon as local Scout leaders can be recruited and trained.

results.snippet: HOW MY PARENTS LEARNED TO EAT    By Ina R. Friedman.  Illustrated by Allen Say.  32 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.  $12.95. (Ages 6 to 9)    HIGH on the list of standard questions that Japanese reserve for Westerners is whether they can use...
results.lead_paragraph: HOW MY PARENTS LEARNED TO EAT By Ina R. Friedman. Illustrated by Allen Say. 32 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 6 to 9) HIGH on the list of standard questions that Japanese reserve for Westerners is whether they can use chopsticks. Many resident foreigners have to suppress the recurring temptation to ask in reply whether their hosts know how to handle knives and forks. But East and West meet finally across the dinner table in this understated tale about the courtship of a Japanese schoolgirl and an American sailor whom she meets while he is stationed in Yokohama.

headline.main: TEACHERS AIM HIGH AT SPACE CAMP

results.snippet: Forty teachers from around the United States spent this weekend experiencing weightlessness and flying a mock shuttle mission at a space camp here, hoping the experience would give them an edge when the first private citizen to fly in space is...
results.lead_paragraph: Forty teachers from around the United States spent this weekend experiencing weightlessness and flying a mock shuttle mission at a space camp here, hoping the experience would give them an edge when the first private citizen to fly in space is chosen by the space agency. President Reagan announced in August that an elementary or high school teacher would be the first ''citizen passenger'' to fly into space aboard the space shuttle, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is to begin accepting applications Dec. 1, an agency official told the educators at the space camp. Dream 'Might Come True' Michael A. DiSpezio, a high school science teacher from Cataumet, Mass., said the knowledge he gained in three days here at the Alabama Space and Rocket Center's space camp and museum would help him stand out from the thousands of teachers who are expected to apply for a shuttle ride. ''I know they say 80,000 may apply,'' Mr. DiSpezio said, but ''with what I've experienced this weekend I feel like my dream just might come true.''

headline.main: PANELISTS SAY JOINT ADVENTURES IN SPACE ARE CRUCIAL TO PEACE

results.snippet: While the presidential candidates argue over the militarization of space, pressures are building to turn space activities back toward peaceful and cooperative ventures with the United States and the Soviet Union working in harness.   Congress has...
results.lead_paragraph: While the presidential candidates argue over the militarization of space, pressures are building to turn space activities back toward peaceful and cooperative ventures with the United States and the Soviet Union working in harness. Congress has unanimously passed a resolution, now awaiting President Reagan's approval or rejection, that would commit the country to seek cooperation in a broad range of space activities with the Soviet Union, ranging from joint space rescue programs to manned exploration of the solar system. Today, at a symposium on long- range proposals to build a permanent base on the moon, Government and private speakers portrayed space as the last and best hope for achieving peace between adversarial nations. James M. Beggs, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the sponsor of the three-day symposium, said that a manned lunar base ''would be an enormous challenge'' requiring new technologies and large economic resources, all of which implied, he said, the need for ''international sharing of risks and benefits.''
